title: Disrupter attacks platform fees
text:
But just when the market had became convinced the specialist platforms would win from lighting the competitive fire under the incumbents a new disrupter has emerged with a radically different business model.

FinClear, a company backed by a range of wealthy investors including Gary Weiss and Afterpay’s foundation shareholder David Hancock, is about to attack the challengers with a new, low-cost wrap platform.

Chief executive David Ferrall says FinClear's opportunity came because the specialist platforms which arrived to eat the lunch of the big incumbent players made one simple mistake.

They were too greedy, Ferrall says. Instead of passing on the benefits of new technology, the specialist platform providers retained all the opaque fees and charges that were the hallmark of the big players.

“To be fair, the platforms generally perform a good service,” Ferrall says. “But they replicated the custodial infrastructure of the bank-owned wrap platforms with all their hidden costs.”

He says the median cost of administration and funds management by the big players is about 1.6 per cent per annum and the specialist platform challengers have charged about 1.56 per cent.

Opaque charges

The beauty of opaque fees and charges is that there can be lots of them and the consumer never really knows what they are paying. He challenges users of all platforms to ask their provider about account-keeping fees, cash fees, transactional fees, brokerage fees and fund manager fees.

Advertisement

Ferrall says the worst of all these charges is the discounted rate on deposits held with specialist platforms. He calls this a “cash skim” because instead of paying market deposit rates the platforms skim off 50 to 100 basis points.

He believes users of platforms are paying about $1 billion in fees that they don't need to.

Ferrall’s product, which will be launched at the offices of Goldman Sachs in Sydney on Monday, dispenses with the costly custodial ownership approach to administering client assets in favour of the holder identification number, which is an electronic record of share ownership developed about 25 years ago by the ASX.

FinClear plans to offer a managed account service using HINs to record the electronic ownership of portfolios of shares. Essentially, the HIN approach allows shares to be held in an electronic filing cabinet in the name of the investor.

The disruption here is in the replacement of the platform custodial system which puts a third party between investors and their shares.

FinClear’s existing operations in the wholesale execution and clearing of shares means it can offer financial advisers an integrated platform or it can allow stockbrokers to use their own infrastructure and licensing alongside FinClear's management of portfolios and implementation of trades.

If FinClear is successful, the term burning platform will have new meaning in the wrap platform space.
description: The days of opaque fees and charges in the wealth management platform space could be numbered if a fintech start-up is successful in disrupting a segment of financial services already experiencing intense competition.
